articles.headline: 4 Accused in Law Firm Fraud Ignored a Maxim: Don’t Email
articles.snippet: It is nearly unheard-of for prosecutors to contend that the top brass of a law firm, especially a once-storied firm like Dewey, was effectively running a corrupt organization.
articles.abstract: It is nearly unheard-of for prosecutors to contend that the top brass of a law firm, especially a once-storied firm like Dewey, was effectively running a corrupt organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:07 p.m. | Several former leaders of the once-high-flying law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf apparently violated a cardinal rule that lawyers always tell their clients: Don’t put anything incriminating into an email.

articles.headline: Abortion Law Pushes Texas Clinics to Close Doors
articles.snippet: The last abortion clinics in two poor and working-class regions were closing, and the number of Texas clinics, once at 44, is expected to fall to six.
articles.abstract: The last abortion clinics in two poor and working-class regions were closing, and the number of Texas clinics, once at 44, is expected to fall to six.
articles.lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Tex. — Shortly before a candlelight vigil on the sidewalk outside, employees of the last abortion clinic in the Rio Grande Valley in South Texas shut the doors early Thursday evening, making legal abortion unavailable in the poorest part of the state in the wake of tough new restrictions passed last year by the Texas Legislature.

articles.headline: Book Deal Falls Apart for Parodist of Goldman
articles.snippet: John LeFevre, the man behind the @GSElevator Twitter account, has lost his book deal after his true identity came to light.
articles.abstract: John LeFevre, the man behind the @GSElevator Twitter account, has lost his book deal after his true identity came to light.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:19 p.m. | Two weeks ago, with a huge online following and a new six-figure book contract, John LeFevre was riding as high as some of the Wall Street traders he parodied in his Twitter account, @GSElevator.
articles.byline: By Leslie Kaufman and William Alden

articles.headline: Bitcoin’s Mysterious Creator Is Said to Be Identified
articles.snippet: A Newsweek article contends that a man in Southern California named Satoshi Nakamoto was the creator of the virtual currency Bitcoin, but many people say they are unconvinced.
articles.abstract: A Newsweek article contends that a man in Southern California named Satoshi Nakamoto was the creator of the virtual currency Bitcoin, but many people say they are unconvinced.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:31 p.m. | Even as it has grown into a new type of digital money worth billions of dollars, Bitcoin has always retained an air of mystery.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Republican’s Tax Plan Awkwardly Aims at Rich
articles.snippet: The Tax Reform Act of 2014 proposed by Dave Camp, a Michigan Republican, contains provisions to take away benefits from some taxpayers simply because they make too much money.
articles.abstract: The Tax Reform Act of 2014 proposed by Dave Camp, a Michigan Republican, contains provisions to take away benefits from some taxpayers simply because they make too much money.

articles.headline: Companies Test Plans to Cut Their Health Costs
articles.snippet: Some employers are offering as many as 25 health care plans to employees from a variety of insurers, including Blue Cross and UnitedHealthcare, to lower their costs for the benefit.
articles.abstract: Some employers are offering as many as 25 health care plans to employees from a variety of insurers, including Blue Cross and UnitedHealthcare, to lower their costs for the benefit.
articles.lead_paragraph: At Walgreen, the giant drugstore chain, employees now have a much broader choice of insurers and plans. Once limited to two options, either from a local Blue Cross plan or UnitedHealthcare, workers can now choose among as many as 25 plans from five insurers, depending on where they live, including Kaiser Permanente, the well-known California-based H.M.O.

articles.headline: The Sweet, Streaming Sound of Data
articles.snippet: With the music industry turning digital, music companies can now understand their customers’ listening habits in greater depth than ever before.
articles.abstract: With the music industry turning digital, music companies can now understand their customers’ listening habits in greater depth than ever before.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once, all you needed to succeed in the music business were a pair of golden ears and some hustle. Now, it also takes mountains of data.

articles.headline: World’s Biggest Arms Importer, India Wants to Buy Local
articles.snippet: The country recently rolled out its own fighter jet and tank and several ships, a defense lineup that could put Russian arms exports in trouble.
articles.abstract: The country recently rolled out its own fighter jet and tank and several ships, a defense lineup that could put Russian arms exports in trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Of the 30 countries that attended a defense exposition last month to sell weapons to India, the world’s largest arms importer, only the Russians had the chutzpah to dress up their tanks and guns with women in tightfitting camouflage.

articles.headline: For First Time, Kremlin Signals It Is Prepared to Annex Crimea
articles.snippet: Leaders of both houses of Russia’s Parliament said that they would support a vote by Crimeans to break away from Ukraine, ignoring sanctions threats and warnings from the U.S. and other countries.
articles.abstract: Leaders of both houses of Russia’s Parliament said that they would support a vote by Crimeans to break away from Ukraine, ignoring sanctions threats and warnings from the U.S. and other countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia signaled for the first time on Friday that it was prepared to annex the Crimea region of Ukraine, significantly intensifying its confrontation with the West over the political crisis in Ukraine and threatening to undermine a system of respect for national boundaries that has helped keep the peace in Europe and elsewhere for decades.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers, David M. Herszenhorn and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: As Job Creation Increases in February, Economists See Signs of a Spring Thaw
articles.snippet: The American economy added more jobs in February than in either of the two months preceding it, suggesting winter weather had been the primary obstacle to growth.
articles.abstract: The American economy added more jobs in February than in either of the two months preceding it, suggesting winter weather had been the primary obstacle to growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy appeared to emerge from a winter hibernation in February, creating more jobs than in either of the previous two months and suggesting that momentum in the labor market might gradually build with the arrival of spring.
